citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
Following a facility records review and discussions with facility personnel there were multiple occasions where the facility
did not assure its attending veterinarian (AV) had the appropriate authority to ensure adequate veterinary care and
oversee its animal care program.
Five horses used in the Veterinary Technician Program were given Phenylbutazone or Banamine without prior knowledge
or direction by the campus veterinarians. The AV stated there is no blanket SOP to treat the horses as the campus
veterinarians evaluates them on a case-by-case basis.
According to medical records the following horses were given Phenylbutazone (Bute) or Banamine on dates indicated by
the EUSM:
-Jazz, 19-year-old mare, received 1-2 grams of Bute 10/14 to 10/16/2019, 12/14/2020, 03/19 to 3/20/2020, and 04/01 to
04/05/2021.
-Belle, 12-year-old mare, received 1-2 grams of Bute on 01/11 to 1/12/2021.
-Lacy, 19-year-old mare, received 1-2 grams of Bute on 02/04 to 02/08/2021.
-Smarty, 13-year-old mare, received 1-2 grams of Bute on 05/21 to 05/22/2020.
-Purdy, 12-year-old mare, received a dose of Banamine paste on 2/25/21 Records show there was an attempt to contact
campus veterinarians, but they were not available at this time
The AV stated there was no communication from the EUSM to inform campus veterinarians of issues of lameness or
other health issues which were identified, treated, and/or resolved in the above indicated horses during these time
periods.
On 10/23/2023, by recommendation of the backup veterinarian, the Farm Manager and EUSM made a decision to send a
horse, Dutton, for an elective surgery. There was no prior approval from the AV/campus veterinarians to transport Dutton
and authorize surgery including post-operative treatment, which is not consistent with the facility’s Animal Care Program
of Veterinary Care Guidelines.
During discussions with the AV, there were no horses negatively affected during these occurrences and corrective action
to improve communication and ensure the AV has adequate authority over the facility’s animals has been set in place.
The attending veterinarian/ campus veterinarians have the knowledge and expertise in the care and treatment of the
facility’s animals. Failure of animal unit personnel to communicate or consult with the attending veterinarian/ campus
veterinarians concerning medical issues does not give them the authority to recommend and approve treatments as
necessary to ensure the health and well-being of the facility’s animals. Each research facility shall assure the attending
veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of
other aspects of animal care and use.
To be corrected from this day forward 5/1/2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
